newsitem.title: MACAU: Macau minister says China arms ban may go - LUSA.
newsitem.headline: Macau minister says China arms ban may go - LUSA.

text.p: Portuguese Defence Minister Antonio Vitorino said on Monday that the current ban on European Union arms sales to China may be lifted soon, the Portuguese national news agency LUSA reported.
"It is natural that the issue (of arms sales) will have to be re-examined" since relations between China and the EU were being normalised, Vitorino was quoted as saying in Beijing.
The faxed LUSA report, monitored by Reuters in Macau, did not specify in what context Vitorino was speaking.
The defence minister arrived in Beijing on Monday on a six-day visit aimed at improving political ties and military cooperation with China.

Vitorino was expected to discuss the 1999 handover of Portuguese-administered Macau to China as well as NATO expansion plans in talks with his Chinese hosts, but would sign no military agreements, LUSA said.
The daily Macau Hoje newspaper said last week that Beijing was interested in selling military equipment to Lisbon, viewing Portugal as a gateway to the European market for Chinese weaponry.

But LUSA quoted the minister as saying on Monday that he was not visiting China "to sell or buy arms", stressing the issue of arms sales to China could not be solved on an exclusively bilateral level.
The European Union banned arms sales to China following the crackdown on student demonstrations in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989, LUSA noted.
Vitorino would visit units of China's three million-strong People's Liberation Army near Beijing, including an air force guided missile division, LUSA said.
He was scheduled to meet Chinese Defence Minister Chi Haotian and President Jiang Zemin on Tuesday, and would travel to Xi'an and Shanghai later in the week, it said.
Vitorino's China visit is the first by a Portuguese defence minister since the two countries established diplomatic ties 18 years ago, LUSA said.
